text: today on hot thai kitchen we're making pla gapong neung manao sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen

today we're making possibly my favorite fish 
dish ever we're making pla gapong neung manao
now okay let's break it down pla means fish gapong is a variety of fish that we typically used

for this dish and that's a barramundi and neung 
means to steam and manao means lime so it's a

steamed fish that has lime as a major flavor so 
let's get started we're going to make the sauce

first because the fish does not take very long to 
cook at all so you want to make sure the sauce is

ready to go for when the fish is done I've got 
here three tablespoons of chopped garlic now

that looks like a lot it is but trust me this is 
what you want it's going to be really good to this

I'm going to add two to three tight chilies that I 
chopped up to about this big when I make food for

other people I kind of I like to keep the chilies 
big enough so that it if people want to pick it

out they don't want to eat too spicy they can it's 
big enough so they can pick it out but if you're

just cooking for yourself and you know you like 
it spicy you can finely chop it and make it more

spicy okay so to that we're going to add a quarter 
cup of lime juice fresh lime juice for this this

is the major flavor and then our salty component 
three tablespoons of fish sauce in there and then

to cut the acid and the salt always a little bit 
of sweet I've got two tablespoons of palm sugar

syrup now I'm using palm sugar syrup here because 
we're not cooking this sauce so if I chop the palm

sugar it's going to have a hard time dissolving 
so what I do is I keep a little jar of palm sugar

syrup so I have it ready to go when I need to use 
it in a cold application and that's half a cup of

chopped palm sure and three tablespoons of water 
just cook it until everything is dissolved keep

it in the little jar I only make a little bit at 
a time because it tends to crystallize over time

so that amount works perfect so now we to this 
we also have about 1/4 cup of chopped cilantro

but I'm not going to add it to the sauce just yet 
because I want the cilantro to be fresh and green

when we go to use it and that's it that's all our 
sauce optional ingredient some people like to add

pickled garlic now pickled garlic it's a it's 
a salty and sweet pickle you can add just about

you know a tablespoon of the garlic and then a 
teaspoon or so of the pickling liquid it adds

another layer of flavor but it's not necessary the 
fish will be just fine with this I just wanted to

let you know that that's an option so we're going 
to let this sit while we prep the fish and during

this time the garlic and the chili and the lime 
everything that all the flavors just going to

mingle and marry and make this a more cohesive 
dish ok so let that sit and let's look at our fish

so this is our black propone or a barramundi it's 
also known as the Asian sea bass I believe it's

actually native to Australia but if you can't find 
it you don't have to use this fish you can use any

sort of white mild flavored fish I've done this 
with sea bream I've done it with tilapia other

types of basses is work as well about one to one 
and a half pound in weight would be good you can

go bigger definitely but the only thing is you 
have to make sure it fits into your steamer so

I've got this and Oh a good a good sign or you 
can look forward to know that a fish is fresh

is that the eyes are still clear and hasn't gone 
cloudy it's best to use a whole fish for this dish

rather than a fillet because when we steam the 
whole fish is going to to release this juice it's

like a self-made fish stock and that juice is an 
important part of our sauce it's going to become

a part of our sauce so and as in cooking meat on 
the bones of all kinds chicken beef whatever the

bones add flavor and it also keeps the the meat 
more moist ok so whole fish if you can now we're

going to score the thickest part of the fish a 
couple times on each side when you cook a whole

fish this part is always going to be thinner and 
cook faster whereas this part is thicker so you

make scoring marks they'll cook more evenly and 
when we go to put the sauce on it it will be more

surface area for the sauce to penetrate now the 
fishmonger should have gutted the fish and cleaned

it for you and scaled it this is totally my trick 
it's not another recipe I like to stuff some

lemongrass in the tummy just for you know just 
cuz I always have lemongrass sitting around and

it's nice it's a nice accent but you don't have to 
go buy lemongrass for this I'm also going to trim

the tail a little bit just because it sticks out 
a little bit out of beyond my plate you don't have

to you can see the trim the fins of you on make it 
easier to eat but I'm going to leave it okay now

plate taking the plate was the hardest thing for 
me because you need to find a plate that's deep

enough so that the sauce has room to go and long 
enough for the fish and that fits in you to your

steamer so over rectangular plate is great because 
you have room on the side so visualize a steamer

when you go to get the plate out if you have room 
on the side it makes it easy the plate is round

you have very little room around the edges and it 
makes taking the plate out kind of awkward so this

is perfect so we're going to take this and steam 
it for seven to ten minutes you don't do anything

to it all this also go in at the end so I've got 
a steamer here with the water on full boil and I'm

going to steam the fish in there now always open 
the steamer away from you so the steam doesn't

rush into your face and if you want if you're 
afraid of steamed board you can turn the heat off

momentarily while you do this and in goes the fish 
close it make sure it's on high vigorously boiling

what it look at okay so this is our 
this is our fish you can see it's

nice and cooked and you can see this 
liquid pooling on the bottom that's

what we want that's going to actually be a 
part of our sauce so this thing is really

handy and I've got a plate here lined with 
wet paper towel so that it doesn't slide

we're going to finish it off here so I've 
got some Chinese celery while it's still

hot we're going to stuff it on the side for 
garnish as well as it's a nice accompaniment

flavor-wise to it as well and the heat of the 
fish will sort of wilt it a little bit yeah

and then we're going to mix our cilantro in 
with the sauce and then we're going to pour

it onto the fish and that's it this is dr. pol 
Mingma now or steamed fish with garlic and lime

again my favorite fish dish in the world 
hope you enjoy it and for the full recipe

visit hot thai kitchen calm and I will see you 
next time for your next delicious Thai meal
